Buds of Glory: The lesser known sports of Roses

23/04/2023

Cara Doherty (she/her) reminds us that there are way more sports on over Roses weekend then you can imagine

Image by Luke Snell

By Orla McAndrew

When (rugby) tackling this article, I had to question what exactly a â€˜lesser knownâ€™ sport looks like. As a person that has not done nor thought about my closest connection to sports - the infamous twice a week PE lesson - in almost 4 years, I worried my vision was skewed. Perhaps Octopush, a 6x6 non-contact sport better understood by its alternative name â€˜underwater hockeyâ€™, has long been making waves. While American football exists on my own periphery, I think of cousins up in Scotland who traveled 13 hours all the way to Nashville to catch their beloved NFL. Who am I to decide what is lesser known and what is leading the proverbial race? Rather than face this slightly existential question head-on, I have tried within this article to simply offer a brief tour of the track, to shine a floodlight on some sports that Iâ€™ve enjoyed learning a little bit more about and am excited to see make their mark on Roses 2023.

Any sport with â€˜Octopusâ€™ in its title is a good place to start, and this fast-paced take on hockey, complete with a weighted puck and snorkeling equipment, is sure to keep spectators on tenterhooks (or tentacles?). The clubâ€™s instagram @uoyoctopush details a â€œgreat improvement from last yearâ€ with a 5th place finish in the Student Nationals back in February. A fun fact about the sport is that players are not allowed to make eye contact with other competitors unless they are in possession of the puck - but the eyes of York are firmly on this teamâ€™s attempt to turn Roses white.

Back on dry land, I had the opportunity to speak to Grace Millington, the social secretary of York Korfball. â€œThe easiest way to describe korfball is that it is a mixture between basketball and netball.â€ explains Grace, a York masters student who started playing about 4 years ago during her undergraduate degree at Newcastle. â€œIt is a mixed gender sport and there are no set positions - everyone gets the chance to play both attack and defence.â€ The aim of the game is to get the ball through the eponymous Korf - a three-metre high yellow hoop. Asked her favourite thing about the sport, she cites the fact that â€œit is so inclusive - anybody is welcome, no matter their age, ability, gender etc.â€

The club features a mixture of university and non-university students, so itâ€™s also a great way to meet new people. Grace tells me about York Korfballâ€™s exciting year as a club, with their first team currently just three wins away from being top of their league. â€œThis season has also been the first year that the club has introduced a second team, which has been really good because it has meant that more people have had the opportunity to play competitively in league matches.â€

Finally and perhaps most importantly, how is the club feeling about the upcoming Roses tournament? With a loss to Lancaster last year, they are hoping to redeem themselves. â€œHopefully being on our home turf with lots of support around us will help us to do that and to prove that Roses definitely are white!â€. Determined and focused, and with an eye to picking up more players for the future too - â€œRoses for us is also a great opportunity to show people what korfball actually is, and how fun it is, so if youâ€™re around you should definitely come and watch the game.â€ Catch them at 09:30 on Saturday 29 April in Arena 3 of the York Sports Centre.

Canoe Polo describes itself as an â€œobscure sportâ€ on their YUSU page, but after conducting some research I genuinely wonder why. A combination of polo, basketball and kayaking, two teams of up to eight players try to get the official water polo ball into the nets suspended approximately two metres above the water on either side of the pitch. The extent of protective equipment worn by the players (lifejackets, helmets) is understood after watching a snippet of gameplay; a popular compilation video shows a man capsize and his competitor immediately use his overturned kayak to bounce the ball into the goal.

The game even starts with a bang - named â€˜the sprintâ€™ - where one player from each team races towards the ball thrown by the referee into the centre of the pitch, attempting to gain possession and initiate the match. Expectedly, the kayaks often smash into each other and even overlap, with players essentially ploughing over their competitors. If this isnâ€™t exciting enough, the Ladies team promise an electric atmosphere as they play against old friends - the York team joined up with the Lancaster ladies in the recent Northern University Polo Leagues, but also beat their Roses rivals 7-5 in 2022.

Something even I am a little more familiar with, Futsal is a take on a little underground game called football. â€œPlayed inside on a lined pitch with a slightly smaller ball, it improves your pace, passing, awareness and techniqueâ€ according to the clubâ€™s YUSU page, which also notes that their two menâ€™s and one womenâ€™s team compete in BUCS every year. No stranger to the pressure, these 21 and 22 Roses winners have all to play for.

Some sports, while a little more well-known, are still surprising and welcome additions to the Roses 2023 lineup. The Ballroom and Latin American dance society, for instance, offer a whole host of competitions at both beginner and non-beginner level. Strictly Come Dancing - and Sabbs - fans will already be familiar with this rewarding sport, and YLBS is no stranger to the pressure, competing yearly at the infamous Blackpool Tower Ballroom. Pole exercise is also well-worth a drop-in watch between 13:00 and 20:30 in Hendrix Hall on Saturday 29 April, with competitors of a wide range of abilities. At Roses 2022, York placed first in every category from beginner through to elite - hopefully a sign of good things to come.

On the less traditionally sporty (and hopefully non-contact) side, University of Yorkâ€™s debating team face their Lancaster counterparts. The team travels across the country - everywhere from LSE to Sheffield to Glasgow - deconstructing arguments, so are well-prepared for this battle of the wits. If anyone can prove that Roses really ARE white, my moneyâ€™s on them.

While well-established in the US, I was unaware of the popularity of American football here in the UK. But University of Yorkâ€™s American football team, the York Centurions, have gone from strength to strength since their founding in 2006. With successes in the BUAFL/BUCS leagues since they joined in 2009, the team were looking strong until a stumbling block last month. In a statement released to the clubâ€™s instagram @theyorkcenturions on 1 March, Club President Cameron Campbell announced that the team were forced to withdraw from their playoff fixture against Heriot Watt that weekend, citing a lack of players and injuries that had been plaguing them since Christmas. In the closing words of Campbell, â€œAll eyes now turn to Lancaster and Roses.â€ He insists: â€œWe will be ready.â€ I, for one, am excited to see exactly what this means.

And this is - somehow - not all! With everything from powerlifting to climbing to motorsports on offer, Roses 2023 is swimming with opportunities for spectatorship. Alongside, for instance, catching the popular Opening Ceremonyâ€™s Lacrosse matches, I encourage you to consider learning about something new. The vast majority of the sports listed above offer free taster sessions year-round - perhaps Roses is the perfect opportunity to scout out something to get involved in before the academic year comes to a close!
